Overview of Data and Background Knowledge
After a threatening situation, animals and humans respond in a variety of ways. Initially described by Walter Cannon (Cannon, W. B. 1915) as the Fight or Flight response, the theory has since then been adapted by Dr. Stephen Porges into Polyvagal theory (Porges 2009). This model now includes freezing as an alternative response, and attempts to correlate stress responses to neurohormonal responses. In the face of a situation in which no options seem viable, an individual can either choose to fight, flee (flight) or freeze. We will be using these three types of responses as a framing for potential ways our interviewees responded to the Beirut Blast.

In 2011, Martin Seligman (Seligman 2011) made the hypothesis that PERMA (Positive Emotion, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment) comprises well-being, and argues that the model is helpful for measurement as well as for application (Seligman 2018).

The Character Strengths data was gathered as part of the application process for a social entrepreneurship program before the August 4th, 2020 explosion. After the explosion, to understand deeper changes in entrepreneurial ideation we conducted a second VIA-IS as well as a new questionnaire using the new measures described above. To start the exploration as to the factors which support social entrepreneurs we keep in mind the question: who grows as a social entrepreneur in times of adversity and who reprioritizes the notion of their career trajectory to focus more on self preservation. In 2008 Christopher Peterson (Peterson et al. 2008) demonstrated a positive correlation between the VIA-IS Character Strengths Inventory and the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTGI; Tedeschi & Calhoun, 1996). The PTGI measures growth on the dimensions of Appreciation, New Possibilities, Relating to Others, Spiritual Enhancement and Personal Strength; interestingly, all of these dimensions are relevant for social entrepreneurial ideation. Data validity questions. 
We initially hypothesized that there would be a correlation between CS prepost (Character Strengths Difference in average scores assessed before/after the blast) and Post Traumatic Growth. While there seems to be a slight correlation between CS prepost and PTGI - Appreciation (.33 p-val .14) we cannot at this time with our limited data make any strong statements about Character Strength changes before/after an explosion and PTGI. One factor could be that the time frame for the post test was taken over a 3 month period (December - March 2020) and it might be interesting to study a progression of changes rather than comparing pre and post. Growth takes time and measuring over an extended period confuses the data. Also, assessing people earlier, and therefore closer to the period of the traumatic event may not have left time to metabolize the experience while people who filled in the assessment later have had more opportunities. Another bias that may be influencing the data is potentially the types of people who submit forms early compared to those who wait may also capture proactive people early in the recovery process and procrastinators later in their process. Rather than adding another factor to control for procrastination, I propose future assessments to include deadlines for inclusion into the dataset, or to include time of receipt as an influencing factor.

So what is a theory behind humor and this buffering effect? Humor has been linked to adaptive coping and keeping a ‚Äúlight attitude‚Äù in the face of adversity (Ruch and Hofmann 2017). Humor is also an active response to take when other options are unavailable: people ‚Äúbreak‚Äù the silence with laughter, for example. This may be preventing the processes which lead to Learned Helplessness. Learned helplessness is one way to view the opposite of post traumatic growth for people living in highly chaotic and destabilized situations. Initially Learned Helplessness theory implied that dogs experiencing inescapable shocks learned helplessness and persisted in helpless behavior even when the situation became escapable later. 

Recent research has shed light on the neurological underpinnings of learned helplessness which has application in uncertain times (Maier, S. F., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2016). Previously Learned Helplessness, as the name suggests, theorized that higher level mammals learn helpless behaviors when they are given inescapable negative experiences. Passivity in the face of a changed situation, a situation where it behooves the animal to take action, is the hallmark of learned helplessness. And while that behavior doesn‚Äôt change, our understanding of how it comes to be has. Mammals, when confronted with prolonged adverse situations, develop an unlearned response of passivity. It is possible to overcome this bias towards passivity by learning and exerting control. What behaviors are available to act on?

One additional mechanism could have explanatory strength is the Broaden and Build theory (Fredrickson B. L. 2004) which espouses that positive emotions support people in expansive activities, and taking action builds new capacity for further positive emotion, expansive activities and capacities. Humor combines the psychological insight and research from Fredrickson with the neurological understandings of modern Learned Helplessness theory from (Maier, S. F., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2016). 1. Introduction
The World Health Organization defines ‚Äúfemale genital mutilation‚Äù as a procedure involving removal of or injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons (WHO, 2008). More than 200 million women and girls have undergone female genital cutting (FGC) globally, with an additional 3 million girls under the age of 18 ‚Äúat risk‚Äù each year (WHO, 2008). While the practice varies widely, much research has shown that women who undergo FGC face negative health and social consequences (Ball, 2008; Utz-Billing and Kentenich, 2008; WHO, 2008). FGC is classified into different types (WHO, 2014): Type 1 in- volves removing part or all of the clitoris or the prepuce. Type 2, in- volves removing part or all of the clitoris and labia minora, with or without the labia majora. Type 3, called infibulation or pharaonic, in- volves removing part or all of the external genitalia and narrowing the vaginal orifice by reapproximating the labia minora and/or labia ma- jora. Type 4 encompasses all other harmful procedures to the genitalia
for non-medical reasons. The term sunna, meaning ‚Äúprophetic tradi- tion‚Äù, is generally used to describe non-infibulating forms of FGC.
1.1. The United States
In 1996, the United States Congress banned FGC. In 2000, Brigham and Women's Hospital's African Women's Health Center used census data to estimate that 228,000 girls living in the US had either under- gone or were at risk of FGC. This represented approximately a 35% increase from the 1990 census data (Nour et al., 2006). More recent estimates tell us that 513,000 girls under the age of 18 in the US are now at risk of FGC‚Äîmore than three times the number in 1990 (Goldberg et al., 2016). Researchers attribute this increase in estimated number of girls at risk to increased migration from FGC-practicing countries as well as a change in the estimation technique to include both first and second generation girls (Goldberg et al., 2016).

1.2. The persistence of FGC
Various reasons have been cited for the persistence of FGC including its role as a rite of passage, the preservation of chastity, ensuring marriageability, religious requirements, hygiene, and enhancing sexual pleasure for men (Nour, 2008; WHO, 2008; Mackie and LeJeune, 2009). A systematic review of 21 studies of members of communities that practiced FGC but reside in Western countries pointed to six key factors underpinning FGC: cultural traditions, sexual morals, marriageability, religion, health benefits, and male sexual enjoyment (Berg and Dension., 2013). In almost all the studies included in that review, FGC was referred to as a meaningful and valued cultural practice linked to honor and the preservation of chastity, enforced through community mechanisms. The current study seeks to avoid oversimplifying the practice and immigrants‚Äô perceptions of it by presenting complex and often contrasting views among a diverse set of immigrant women and men.
1.3. Community based research in immigrant populations
Some research has examined perceptions and experiences of FGC in African diasporic communities in the United States (Akinsulure-Smith, 2014; Connor et al., 2016; Johnson et al., 2009; McNeely and Jong, 2016). A qualitative study among 30 female Somali refugees in Min- nesota found that participants endorsed negative attitudes towards FGC, largely secondary to health consequences as well as a new un- derstanding that FGC is not sanctioned religiously (Connor et al., 2016). A qualitative study among 13 Somali refugees in Colorado found that all participants reported having changed their views on FGC after moving, often due to education, migration, and dissociation of the practice from religious beliefs (McNeely and Jong, 2016). Lastly, a study among Somali immigrant women about their challenging FGC- related healthcare experiences in the US emphasized the importance of engaging in community-based participatory research using mixed- methods to build trust-based networks and actively engage community members in the research process (Johnson et al., 2009).
There is also research on FGC among African diasporic communities outside the United States (Abdulcadir et al., 2016; Jaldesa and Abdi 2014; Vloeberghs et al. 2012). A study in Nairobi found that Ethiopian immigrants viewed FGC as a tool to curb female sexuality and enforce fixed gender roles upon women; those researchers called for commu- nity-based education programming involving religious leaders, NGOs, government ministries, and other actors (Jaldesa and Abdi 2014). A study of immigrants from Sub-Saharan Africa residing in Hamburg, Germany found that most immigrants speak out for the abandonment of FGC, but that there is a solid minority who maintain either positive or indifferent attitudes towards the practice (Behrendt, 2011). Other stu- dies also reflect this overwhelming rejection of FGC after immigration (Johnsdotter et al., 2007), while some studies delineate certain groups of immigrants that may tend to have more traditional views towards the practice, such as males, older generations, and new arrivals (Morison et al., 2004). There are differing views on the kind of effect the process of migration has on the viewpoints of immigrants on FGC. One fra- mework might suggest that immigrants may cling more strongly to cultural norms such as FGC in an effort to retain their cultural identity, while an opposing theory might suggest that immigrants are more likely to abandon a practice such as FGC in the process of assimilation (Berry, 1997).
1.4. Men's perspectives
Few studies in the US have explored the varied perspectives of men on FGC. A recent study in Somalia indicated that 96% of men preferred to marry women who have undergone FGC but that women were less likely than men to support FGC (Almroth et al., 2001). Similarly, a study in Oslo found that Somali immigrant men were more likely than

1.5. Objectives
This study documents the FGC-related perceptions and experiences of immigrant women and men in Boston, Massachusetts, and attempts to understand the effect of migration on these perceptions, with the larger goal of optimizing health services and informing public policy to support women who have undergone FGC. Our study is unique in considering not only the views of women who have undergone FGC (not simply all women from FGC-practicing countries), but also the views of immigrant men from the same communities. Furthermore, this study investigates the nature of FGC-related communication between mem- bers of the diaspora and relatives in their communities of origin across Africa and the Middle East‚Äîan important facet of the subject that past studies have not investigated.
2. Methods
We designed a qualitative study consisting of individual interviews in Boston, Massachusetts, with immigrant women who experienced FGC themselves and immigrant men with family members who had experienced FGC, to explore their views on the practice and the dis- course surrounding it. We report our qualitative research in accordance with the COREQ criteria (Tong et al., 2007).
2.1. Ethics, consent, and permissions
This study was approved by the Brigham and Women's Hospital Institutional Review Board (IRB). Informed consent was obtained verbally and participants were provided with a study information sheet. No compensation or incentives were given to study participants.
2.2. Topic guide
The topic guides for the interviews were created by the researchers based on gaps in the literature related to the perspectives and experi- ences of people in the US who immigrated from communities where FGC has been practiced. The topic guides, one tailored to men and the other to women [Appendix A] were reviewed for content, clarity, and cultural sensitivity by Harvard Medical School faculty of both African and Middle Eastern descent. The topic guides consisted of three sec- tions: participants‚Äô personal views on FGC and the cultural and social factors that have affected their views; personal experiences with FGC and its long-term effects; and perceptions of community views of the practice both in their countries of origin and in the US diaspora.
2.3. Sampling
Convenience sampling was used to recruit both women and men living in Boston who had immigrated from communities where FGC has been practiced, including parts of Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Nigeria, Somalia, Sudan, and the United Arab Emirates. Inclusion cri- teria included women and men above 18 years of age who immigrated from these countries and now live in Boston. For women, it was ne- cessary that they themselves had undergone FGC. For men, it was ne- cessary that they had a family member who had undergone FGC. Individuals who were below 18 years of age or women who had not undergone FGC were excluded.

3.5. Changes in perspectives on and practices of FGC
The final theme of our interviews was the potential for change in opinions on FGC, both in immigrants‚Äô communities of origin as well as in the US. The overwhelming majority of participants we interviewed, both men and women, believed that both the prevalence of and popular support for FGC had decreased. Participants attributed this decline to both personal and community-level changes relating to (from most to least commonly attributed) education, urban-rural divides, crim- inalization of FGC, generational differences, emigration, transnational and national campaigns, religious leaders, and medical personnel.
3.5.1. Sources of change
These changes in opinions on FGC were overwhelmingly attributed to increased education, particularly regarding the harms and health risks of FGC. A 31-year-old Somali woman explained succinctly, ‚ÄúThere is a faction that says it [FGC] is something necessary to our culture, and there are some people who see it as a backwards practice. 4. Discussion
Our study sheds light on the views and experiences of immigrant men and women in Boston, Massachusetts originating from a variety of communities where FGC is practiced. Participants expressed a range of rationales for the practice of FGC, and many questioned the validity of these rationales and the continuation of the practice, especially in its most severe forms. Notably, this is among the few studies in which men of the diaspora in the United States have been interviewed on the topic

of FGC. Most male participants strongly opposed the practice due to its effects on their wives' sexual and childbirth experiences. Religion seemed to play a role in participants‚Äô views, both for and against the practice. Participants also cited immigration and education as having significant effects on the changing views regarding the continuation of the practice. Furthermore, many participants considered themselves capable of playing an important role in influencing the discourse around the practice of FGC in their home communities.
Both the Christians and Muslims in our study cited religion as an important factor in both the continuation and curbing of the practice of FGC. While the Quran does not mention FGC, and it is not practiced in most Muslim-majority countries, many Muslim participants said they grew up with the understanding that Islam mandated the practice. Nevertheless, our participants also cited religion, religious leaders, and religious institutions as instrumental in shaping their own views and views in their home communities against FGC. In Johnsdotter's study of Somali women living in Sweden, participants were especially opposed to pharaonic circumcision, as they had developed the belief that it was contrary to basic Islamic principles (Johnsdotter, 2003). Many of our participants admitted that they would not have been able to abandon the practice had they not learned through education, and in many cases immigration, that FGC was not religiously compulsory. Thus, the campaigns of religious leaders and institutions against FGC seem to play a critical role in influencing community perspectives on FGC.
The term sunna, meaning ‚Äúaccording to the tradition of the Prophet Muhammad‚Äù, was generally used by our participants to refer to Type I FGC, but can be used to describe any non-infibulating form of FGC, considered ‚Äòless severe‚Äô than Type III. In some countries such as Somalia, Type I FGC has been harder to eradicate than Type III, termedpharaonic, as the latter carries a non-Islamic name that people seem more ready to question (The World Bank, 2004; Gele et al., 2012). In a few prior studies, including one in Somalia and another among Somali refugees in the US, some women expressed a preference for Type I FGC, seeing it as a safe alternative to Type III for both health and religious reasons (Fried et al., 2013; McNeely and Jong, 2016; Connor et al., 2016). While the Somali women in Fried's study had received unequi- vocal messages from the campaigns of religious leaders and institutions that the practice of Type III FGC was un-Islamic and so had started opposing it, many had received conflicting messages regarding Type I FGC, hearing that it was either prohibited, a religious mandate, or optional (Fried et al., 2013). These mixed messages are reflected in our own study population of men and women living in the US, who were overwhelmingly against the practice of FGC, especially Type III, with some participants having more equivocal views on Type I.
The men in our study collectively took a stand against FGC, espe- cially due to its impact on their wives' health and sexual lives and concern that their daughters might suffer the same. In a study of West African immigrants in New York City, men were found to be as knowledgeable about the health consequences of FGC as women, though with a less nuanced understanding, and were just as likely as women to reject the practice (Akinsulure-Smith and Chu, 2017). An- other study exploring Gambian men's knowledge found that only a minority of men were aware of FGC health consequences, but those who understood its negative impact on the health and well-being of girls and women were very willing to play a role in its prevention (Kaplan et al., 2013). A systematic review of twenty studies on the role of men in abandonment of FGC found that education level was one of the most important indicators for men's support for abandonment of the practice (Varol et al., 2015). Both social obligation and a lack of dia- logue between men and women on the issue were identified as barriers to abandonment.
In one study, men in a Somali community in the US expressed that they play key roles in explaining their own socio-cultural contexts to American healthcare providers and as advocates for their wives in a foreign healthcare system (Johnson-Agbakwu et al., 2014). Similarly, several men in our own study facilitated their wives' access to
healthcare providers at the African Women's Health Center after having negative experiences with physicians with limited awareness of the practice of FGC. Both the men and women in our study discussed the intimate roles of men as supportive husbands, both sexually and emo- tionally, particularly at the time of their wives' first sexual experiences, which many participants described as painful. Most profoundly, many male participants explored their current and potential roles as ad- vocates against the practice of FGC. While they admitted that they had generally thought of the practice as a ‚Äúwomen's issue,‚Äù many had begun to feel that men could play a vital role in curbing the practice in their communities. The men we interviewed believed that they had a parti- cular duty to raise awareness in their families and their communities about the physical and emotional harm FGC can cause and spoke of their roles in dissuading their family and community members from continuing the practice.
In our study, the perceived role of immigration in influencing par- ticipants‚Äô views against FGC cannot be ignored. Many Muslim partici- pants explained that, due to exposure to Muslims immigrating from countries where FGC was not practiced, immigrants felt more ready to question and ultimately dismiss the perceived religious origins of the practice. In this way, immigration seems to provide a space where people of different diasporic communities interact and exchange ideas, a phenomenon supported by prior studies (McNeely and Jong, 2016; Berggren et al., 2006). According to the ‚Äúmodified stages of change‚Äù theory, Shell-Duncan proposes that people abandon the practice of FGC when they find a motivation to do so and when their social context supports, promotes, or at least accepts abandonment, such as in the setting of immigration (Shell-Duncan and Herniund, 2006). A study examining the temporal effect of immigration on attitudes towards FGC found that immigration to Britain from a younger age appeared to be associated with abandonment of FGC and changes in the more tradi- tional beliefs that underpin it (Morison et al., 2004). While we did not demonstrate the same findings as recent immigrants also shared nega- tive views of FGC, our sample size is also small and unlikely to be able to demonstrate such a difference. One theory relevant to this could be the migration selection hypothesis, which posits that those who migrate tend to be wealthier, educated and from urban settings, factors known to be associated with reduced support for FGC (Ortensi et al., 2015). However, our study population had a large proportion of refugees and asylum seekers and did not represent a disproportionately wealthy group.
One framework to understand the abandonment of FGC is the social convention theory of interdependent decision-making. As Mackie and LeJeune describe, FGC is a community practice that traditionally fa- cilitated social belonging and marriageability (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009). Therefore, ending the practice cannot only be an individual endeavor, but requires the entire community, starting with a critical mass of its most influential members, to collectively and publicly abandon it. Remarkably, as the authors emphasize, ‚ÄúThe underlying moral norm of care for one's children, which motivates the decision to practice FGM/C can also inspire communities to reconsider the prac- tice‚Äù (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009, page 2).
As all our participants were aware of US laws outlawing FGC, we asked them specifically about the illegal practice commonly known as ‚Äúvacation cutting,‚Äù in which immigrants are said to attempt to sustain the practice of FGC by returning to their countries of origin with their daughters for the purpose of having them undergo FGC (Goldberg et al., 2016). Based on our qualitative data, immigrants from multiple coun- tries of origin had heard of the practice but did not know of any such cases in their families or communities and found it hard to believe that it was possible, particularly given the legal consequences. There are no reliable sources of data on the prevalence of this practice in the United States (Nour, 2015; Goldberg et al., 2016). New laws are being pro- posed in the US to target these communities to address this practice; however, caution will have to be exercised in the enforcement of these laws so as to avoid racial profiling, especially as the practice has not

As Johnsdotter et al. write in their qualitative study that found firm rejection of all forms of FGC among Ethiopian and Eritrean immigrants in Sweden, ‚ÄúA societal structure prepared to deal with suspected cases of FGC with a high level of alertness should be combined with a healthy skeptical attitude to- ward exaggerations of risk estimates‚Äù (Johnsdotter et al., 2007, page 114).
To our knowledge, this is the first study to specifically explore the current and potential roles of diasporic communities in engaging with the perceptions and practices of FGC in their communities of origin. Participants' responses were mixed; many believed that they already had some influence in dissuading their family and friends from having FGC performed on their daughters. Others had not considered it pre- viously, but affirmed that their participation in this study would inspire them to call their relatives in their countries of origin to discuss the practice. Mackie's social norms theory is interesting to consider in this context: are members of the diaspora influential enough to impact perception and practice in their countries of origin (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009)? More research is required to investigate this question. Based on our findings, research and initiatives that target FGC should incorporate the exchange of ideas and experiences between immigrant communities and their communities of origin, while paying attention to local efforts in communities where FGC is currently practiced.
4.1. Implications and future directions
Our study has several implications. Our participants describe per- sonal and communal change that they attribute to multiple factors in- cluding education, immigration, changing social pressures, and im- proved religious literacy, all of which can be used to promote and support change in practice. Our study also highlights a need for more targeted involvement of already motivated male members of the com- munity in the effort to curb the practice of FGC. Our preliminary ex- ploration of the role of members of the diaspora provides some support for initiatives that would involve emigrants in the effort to curb the practice in home countries. Further research should be conducted to study the efficacy of this approach. Although our study is limited geo- graphically to Boston, Massachusetts, our findings do not support the fear that vacation cutting might be common among US immigrants. We should therefore exercise caution in our promotion of legislation and clinical practices that target this fear.
4.2. Limitations
This study is subject to several limitations. While participants were forthcoming with personal information, the topic of FGC can be sensi- tive not only emotionally, but also legally; it is possible that due to the heavy bias and strict laws in the United States against FGC, participants who looked upon the practice more favorably might have been less forthcoming about topics like vacation cutting or their personal or community views on the topic. Our participants are not intended as a representative sample of the immigrant population in the US, and it is entirely possible that the views of our participants, who presented to the African Women's Health Center or other community centers where they were recruited, might differ from the views of other members of their communities. Additionally, those willing to discuss FGC in a study may represent different attitudes than those who would not choose to participate. Finally, in addition to being a benefit, focusing on im- migrants from multiple countries in our study may mask trends and themes that might be more specific to a specific community or country.
5. Conclusion
Unlike previous studies that focused on only one community/ country of origin, this study documents the perceptions and experiences of immigrant men and women in Boston, Massachusetts, from a wide
variety of communities where FGC is practiced. Many participants questioned the rationales behind FGC in their own lives and felt strongly against the continuation of the practice of FGC. This change in opinion, described by our participants as taking place on both the personal and community levels, was most frequently attributed to education and immigration. Our study provides strong support for the inclusion of men, religious leaders, and immigrants in FGC-related ef- forts. Changing views in the diaspora could play a significant role in affecting opinions and practices in contexts where FGC is prevalent. Finally, none of the participants personally knew of anyone who per- formed vacation cutting, calling into question the concern that vacation cutting might be common among US immigrants. We should therefore exercise caution in our promotion of legislation and clinical practices that target this fear.
